verses.kjv: What shall we say then that Abraham our father, as pertaining to the flesh, hath found?
verses.ct: So what can we say that Abraham, our ancestor, discovered through his own human effort?

verses.kjv: For if Abraham were justified by works, he hath whereof to glory; but not before God.
verses.ct: If Abraham had been made right with God through his actions, he would have had something to brag about — but not in God's presence.

verses.kjv: For what saith the scripture? Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness.
verses.ct: What does Scripture say? "Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness."

verses.kjv: Now to him that worketh is the reward not reckoned of grace, but of debt.
verses.ct: When someone works for pay, their wages aren't considered a gift — they're an obligation.

verses.kjv: But to him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousness.
verses.ct: But for the person who doesn't rely on their own efforts but instead trusts in the one who declares the ungodly righteous, that person's faith is credited as righteousness.

verses.kjv: Even as David also describeth the blessedness of the man, unto whom God imputeth righteousness without works,
verses.ct: David talks about this same blessing when he describes the happiness of someone whom God credits with righteousness apart from anything they've done:

verses.kjv: Saying, Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.
verses.ct: "How happy are those whose wrongdoing is forgiven, whose sins are wiped away.

verses.kjv: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord will not impute sin.
verses.ct: How happy is the person whose sin the Lord will never count against them."

verses.kjv: Cometh this blessedness then upon the circumcision only, or upon the uncircumcision also? for we say that faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousness.
verses.ct: Now, does this blessing apply only to the circumcised, or to the uncircumcised as well? We've been saying that Abraham's faith was credited to him as righteousness.

verses.kjv: How was it then reckoned? when he was in circumcision, or in uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.
verses.ct: So when was it credited? Was it after he was circumcised, or before? It wasn't after — it was before.

verses.kjv: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also:
verses.ct: He received circumcision as a sign, a seal confirming the righteousness that came through faith while he was still uncircumcised. This happened so that he would become the father of all who believe without being circumcised, so that righteousness would be credited to them as well.

verses.kjv: And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised.
verses.ct: He is also the father of the circumcised — not just those who are physically circumcised, but those who also follow the path of faith that our father Abraham walked while he was still uncircumcised.

verses.kjv: For the promise, that he should be the heir of the world, was not to Abraham, or to his seed, through the law, but through the righteousness of faith.
verses.ct: The promise that Abraham and his descendants would inherit the world didn't come through the law. It came through the righteousness that comes from faith.

verses.kjv: For if they which are of the law be heirs, faith is made void, and the promise made of none effect:
verses.ct: If those who depend on the law are the ones who inherit the promise, then faith means nothing and the promise is worthless.

verses.kjv: Because the law worketh wrath: for where no law is, there is no transgression.
verses.ct: The law produces God's anger, because where there is no law, there is no violation of it.

verses.kjv: Therefore it is of faith, that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to all the seed; not to that only which is of the law, but to that also which is of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all,
verses.ct: That's why the promise is based on faith, so that it would be an act of grace — guaranteeing it for all of Abraham's descendants. Not just for those who follow the law, but also for those who share Abraham's faith. He is the father of all of us.

verses.kjv: (As it is written, I have made thee a father of many nations,) before him whom he believed, even God, who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were.
verses.ct: As Scripture says, "I have made you a father of many nations." This was in the sight of the God he trusted — the God who gives life to the dead and speaks of things that don't yet exist as if they already do.

verses.kjv: Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken, So shall thy seed be.
verses.ct: When there was no reason for hope, Abraham held on to hope and believed, so that he would become the father of many nations, just as God had told him, "This is how numerous your descendants will be."

verses.kjv: And being not weak in faith, he considered not his own body now dead, when he was about an hundred years old, neither yet the deadness of Sarah’s womb:
verses.ct: His faith didn't weaken, even though he recognized that his body was practically dead — he was about 100 years old — and that Sarah was also unable to have children.

verses.kjv: He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God;
verses.ct: He didn't waver in doubt at God's promise. Instead, his faith grew stronger, and he gave glory to God,

verses.kjv: And being fully persuaded that, what he had promised, he was able also to perform.
verses.ct: completely convinced that God had the power to carry out what he had promised.

verses.kjv: And therefore it was imputed to him for righteousness.
verses.ct: That is why it was credited to him as righteousness.

verses.kjv: Now it was not written for his sake alone, that it was imputed to him;
verses.ct: The words "it was credited to him" weren't recorded just for Abraham's benefit.

verses.kjv: But for us also, to whom it shall be imputed, if we believe on him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead;
verses.ct: They were written for us too — for all of us who believe in the one who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead. It will be credited to us as well.

verses.kjv: Who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification.
verses.ct: Jesus was handed over to death because of our sins and was raised to life to make us right with God.
